job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Clemson, SC
pros: GRA positions offer an opportunity for graduate students to gain valuable research experience and develop skills relevant to their field of study. Students who are awarded GRA positions typically receive a stipend, tuition remission, and health insurance, which can help offset the costs of pursuing a graduate degree. GRA positions can help students build relationships with faculty members and fellow researchers, which may lead to future career opportunities. By working on research projects, students may have the opportunity to contribute to the advancement of knowledge in their field and make a positive impact in society. Clemson University's ME department is ranked among the top mechanical engineering programs in the country, which can enhance the value of a graduate degree from the department.
cons: GRA positions may be competitive, and not all students who apply may be awarded a position. The workload of a GRA position can be demanding and require significant time and effort outside of coursework. The research focus of a GRA position may not align with a student's personal interests or career goals. Depending on the nature of the research project, the work may be very specialized and not provide a broad range of experiences. The stipend provided may not be sufficient to cover living expenses in the area.

pros: This is a hands-on, outdoor job at Clemson's Coastal Research and Education Center in Charleston, SC. It incorporates science with agriculture and it has been one of the best experiences of my life. Very fun, fast paced, and friendly coworkers and management.

review_title: Beautiful on the outside ugly on the inside
pros: Flexability when needing to take time off...however it can be a disadvantage because some take advantage of the perk. Working with students. Most positions allow for casual attire.
cons: They still run on the "good ole boy" system. The pay is very poor. Benefits are poor..ins is high, state retirement isnt that great anymore, budget cuts for the past 5yrs so no real job security anymore. No real University "perks" (free football tix, tuition discount for children of employees, etc). I have seen many people with great ideas to move the University as a whole or departments forward get passed up for raises/promotions to those who really do nothing. Its a really sad place if you have any morals and hate to see people treated unfairly. I couldn't take seeing people continoiusly be mistreated and choose to seek employment elsewhere. I had worked in different departments on campus and worked with many people in other departments and its the same campus wide. Very low morale campus wide.

pros: The RA position provided a great team environment to work in that developed professional skills, experience, and provided enough compensation to offset some University expenses. Other perks included a single room at the double rate (for housing areas that typically assign two people to a bedroom), flexible schedules that are planned well in advance, and great responsiveness from direct and indirect supervisors and team members.
cons: The compensation is not the best based on what some other university housing programs offer (no free room and board, for example), and you are required to be on call 24/7 on some designated duty nights and weekends (yes, you will more than likely miss at least one home game because of this). The backgrounds of other RA's is very diverse, so there are RA's who go above and beyond the job description (over-stepping and potentially difficult to work with) as well as those who do the absolute bare minimum.

job_title: Student Services Coordinator in Clemson, SC
pros: It's super hard to get fired!
cons: Where to begin...There is a large gap of respect with administration between faculty and staff?  Have an issue, better believe faculty are going to get their way.  I have exceptional job reviews every year but never get a raise unless the state awards one (last one was 3%, but the state required we increase retirement contributions by 1.5%.  So I got a 1.5% raise).  That was 3 years ago.  The only way to get more pay is to go to another position.  Staff are overworked and unappreciated/under paid.  Most seasoned staff have just given up and are coasting until retirement.  New staff try desperately to make a change but no one listens to them.  They then get burned out and then either leave or give up and coast.  First day on the job, I was told by a fellow co-worker to "never volunteer for anything."  They were right.  If you volunteer for something, guess what, that is now part of your job duties.  Do you get compensated for it?  No.

review_title: A university with strong goals, which has pros and cons, but mostly pros.
pros:
A really strong culture of loyalty built around sports and school spirit so depending on your preference, that can be really fun or it can be really off-putting. Most people who embrace it are really nice so it makes it easy to join the fun. Because of this unity, it makes working there feel inclusive and energetic. 

The campus is really beautiful and walkable. Lots of surrounding area for outdoor recreation. The town is small and nestled in a rural area, which worked for me, but if you are more big city-oriented, this might not work for you. Clemson attracts a diverse, international crowd, so there is still a bit of culture here, but not as much as other campuses to which I've been.
cons: Very strong conservatism, so again, depending on your preferences in lifestyle, politics, beliefs, this can be good or bad. People are friendly, but conservative culture rules. Can you tell I'm quite liberal? The "good ol'boys" club is stlll alive and well here.

review_title: Great IT start for undergraduate and graduate students that need a part time job.
pros: Very Flexible Schedules for part time students, great bosses, great atmosphere for learning.  This is the best place to work for Computer Science, Computer Engineering and other IT type of majors.  This is only a place where Clemson University students can work  (the helpdesk) so I don't expect many people to be reading this review.  It is a very great place to start your career and they don't kid that there is not that many full time jobs available at Clemson University in IT development.
cons: Tedious and can be just resetting people's passwords over and over.  Sometimes you will get the occasional bad customer that yells at you but most of the time it is very chill.  Try to get shifts at Cooper and you will have the easiest on campus job around.

review_title: Great university with a bright future
pros:
- Strong leadership
-Great academic reputation
- Attention to scholarly and research mission
-Warm and welcoming community
-Smart and helpful colleagues
- Beautiful region of the country, especially if you like outdoor activities
- The president is a dynamic leader who represents the university very well at all times.
cons:
- Clemson is a small town and while Greenville is nearby and is a very nice mid-sized community, those looking for a thriving arts and culture scene may be disappointed. (Atlanta, Charlotte and Asheville are all within 2 hours, though).

- Change comes a bit slowly at times, despite an ambitious leadership team. University pride and a love of tradition can sometimes morph into resistance to change.

- Pay and benefits are OK, but not great.

- Staffing is thin in many areas.

job_title: Lower Lever Student Affairs Employee in Clemson, SC
pros:
- Compensation is decent and there's a fair amount of job security.
- Cost of living is fairly low. Not too far from Asheville, Greenville, and to a lesser degree, Charlotte and Atlanta. 
- Work/life balance was solid, only a few times where I was overloaded with work.
cons:
- I know it's cliche, but everything revolves around money at Clemson. If an initiative benefits the students, it's only icing on the cake for the administration – they're just looking to appease donors. (Not to begin with the Greek Life mess they've got going on over there...) If you're looking to work for a group of people that are trying to advance education, you should look elsewhere. 
- Leadership is hilariously terrible at communication, and the further up the ladder you go, the more negativity dominates the work culture.

job_title: Admin Assistant II in Clemson, SC
pros: Job security as university progress has had steady growth.
cons: True salary growth seems stunted. When salary increases, it seems only to alleviate increase in insurance, retirement and parking premiums.

job_title: Director of Information Technology in Clemson, SC
pros: Clemson University is a great place to work.  There is plenty of support for anyone who is wanting to further their professional development or even just to expand their knowledge through edication.  Educational opportunities abound and are supported bu management.
cons: Working for the state of SC has its challenges.  Our government has relied on consumption to provide revenue for government, including higher education.  This has made the recent downturn in the economy and the resulting budget cuts very challenging.

review_title: An innovative work environment moving at a relaxed pace.
pros: Highly relaxed work environment.  Opportunity to contribute to the direction of projects in which you are involved.  High job security.
cons: Low to inadequate compensation.  Employees on average do not share the level of motivation seen in their counterparts in the private sector.  Leadership often consists of relics of a past day and age who have been promoted to their current position by outlasting the competition in employment term.

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Clemson, SC
pros: Very friendly and relaxed environment. Professors are generally nice and get to know you instead of just giving you work. You never have to grade anything, but you do have to attend UTA hours at least once a week (3 hours from 7PM-10PM). Again, it is relaxed and you get to control the environment with out any professors unless you get a ton of students who procrastinated till the night before their project is due and they have a million questions.
cons: I honestly could not tell you who my direct boss/supervisor was, but that was because I became a UTA after the semester started probably. Other than that I would say there are really no cons. I loved being a UTA for solidworks.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Greenville, SC
pros: Minimum salary as per the base range, $20,000; tuition fee waiver; Accommodation affordable in Clemson
cons: Anything above the minimum as per the negotiations with the advisor; Semester wise fee of about $1400-$1700 due for each semester; Student needs to be enrolled even in the summer semester ($1000-1200 fee) for eligibility of salary; Accommodation in Greenville is relatively expensive compared to Clemson, salary for Greenville graduates not adjusted for difference in cost of living compared to the city of Clemson.

pros: Being an employee at Clemson has many perks, but for me, I love the work-life balance that my job provides. The work hours are manageable and I am able to take care of life outside of work as needed. It is also a place that is consistently growing and changing which is exciting to see as an employee. Not to mention, this place is BEAUTIFUL. Coming from corporate life to the higher education setting has been a wonderful change.
cons: The positives absolutely outweigh any negative.

review_title: It's great place to work and money-saving place to live
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Clemson, SC
pros: Uplifting momentum for whole university. BMW built a manufacture plant 40 miles away and collaborate with Clemson in the CU-International Center of Auto Research. Great opportunity for mechanical engineering majored people. Living expense is really low comparing to north and CA. It takes usually less or around 200k to purchase a decent house in decent neighborhood. Retirement plan is great.
cons: Not much fun place. Asian grocery and food is not quite good in town. People around you are mostly conservative. The whole town is empty during holiday, especially Thanksgiving and Christmas.

review_title: Research Assistant in an experimental science lab for 3 years
pros: The hours are very flexible, you can complete research more or less at your own pace provided you are cleared to operate all the instruments you need solo. Independence is generally afforded and taking the initiate to start projects and collaborate is rewarded.
cons: The pay is not outstanding relative to peer institutions. If you aren't a self-starter it's easy to spend a lot of time doing nothing since there isn't much micromanaging. The city of Clemson is small and boring if you're used to city living.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Clemson, SC
pros: It was very flexible, I was just expected to get my research and writing finished but I could work pretty much whatever hours I wanted.  The pay was the going rate for an RA.  The campus is beautiful, I had done my undergraduate there so transition was easy.  There's always events and things going on around campus so you were never bored.
cons:
For my particular research, it was easy to slack off because no one was really keeping tabs, so that happened a lot until I got my act together and finished what I needed to for graduation.  
Not a top flight university, but working with the right professor you can make the most of it.

job_title: Assistant Professor, Tenure Track in Clemson, SC
pros:
* Very prideful alumni and students; lot of school spirit 
* Generally motivated students
* Growing institution
cons:
* Some office and classroom spaces are comically outdated 
* Very much air of arrogance and toward faculty, who are seen as disposable and are not valued. Can be described by statement “you are lucky to be here”
* Extremely homogeneous student body, only lip service is paid to embracing diversity by leadership with no substance 
* Current academic leadership has shown itself on numerous instances to be lacking any type of moral compass or courage to do what is right. 
* “Kick the can down the road” or burying heads in the sand are most common reactions to legitimate issues

job_title: Grounds Specialist III in Clemson, SC
pros: Great atmosphere. Continued education. Health, dental, vision, life insurance. Retirement. Incredible PTO. Paid holidays. Many different employee appreciation events. Clemson works hard to be inclusive and make all of their employees feel valued, and in turn makes me driven to give great results.
cons: Not much room for upward movement within the department or field.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Clemson, SC
pros: The teaching assistantship grants a tuition waiver and small stipend.  Which enables students to afford the expense of graduate school.  The program is supportive and the work takes a small amount of time which means I can focus my studies with relatively little interference.
cons: There is little support or oversight for TAs.  This could be good and bad.  It's good for me because I can spend less time on these duties.  However, student learning suffers as a result.  I suspect students get little out of their interactions with me because I have no training in teaching.

review_title: "Graduate Assistant" with more responsibilities than supervisor.
pros: Great environment and location. The weather is awesome most of the year and having the lake nearby is a lot of fun.
cons: Graduate assistants are generally underpaid across the board. Mine specifically demanded more time than my course work did and having a personal life was almost impossible.

review_title: Nice place to live and work
job_title: Environment Health Manager III in Clemson, SC
pros: Dedicated people, collaborations between departments is not uncommon.  This is a beautiful area in which to live.  Clemson is on Lake Hartwell, and other lakes are nearby.  The mountains are close.  Close to Greenville, which is a cool city.  Close enough to Atlanta and Asheville for day trips.  Encouraged by hiring of new president
cons: Professor compensation good; staff compensation lacking.  University seems to have lost sight of its agriculture/land grant origins in its recent quest to be a top 20 public university.

review_title: Clemson is an easy (not necessarily a great) place to work.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Clemson, SC
pros: There is a very relaxed atmosphere. The cost of living is also very low. The surrounding area is beautiful and full of opportunity for top-notch outdoor recreation. It would also be a nice place to start a family.
cons: It is often difficult to understand why decisions are made. Parking is very difficult, sometimes impossible.  Clemson as a town sucks: pizza, burgers, wings and crappy bars. Don't plan on eating out on Sunday; most decent places are closed.

pros: I love the location and the upstate of South Carolina.  Our office has a familial culture and has been a great place to work and grow.  Higher education offers a flexible schedule and great benefits such as employees are offered free tuition for up to 6 hours a semester.
cons: Decisions are mostly made by the Board of Trustees and Provost and don't always seem logical or in touch with the true needs of the colleges and students.

review_title: better go UPIC jobs than regular oncampus jobs
job_title: Creative Director Decipher in Clemson, SC
pros:
Better pay than regular minimum wage on campus jobs. 
$1 increment on every returning semester.
Get internship credit on your transcript
cons: Depending on job might have to work with cross functional teams where the other interns work as if they are doing a favor for the university. They forget as employees they should provide the best they can and your boss has the rights to reject under quality works and ask you to re do it.

pros:
- Great atmosphere, everyone is happy to work there because they support the school in some way
- Management and bosses are family oriented and care about the people who work for them
cons:
- Very rural. Closest big-ish city is Greenville, about 45 minutes away
- Environment can be kind of oppressive, like a high school vibe

review_title: Great, relaxed place to have a student job.
pros: It is easy money, requires little training and even effort to do the job, and pays better than many places on campus. The hours are also as flexible as you want them to be.
cons: Since it is a student job, most of your bosses are students, which leads to cliquey groups that can make the environment less than appealing for some, and also hinders promotions.

pros: Select group of top professors
cons: If you are offered a Teaching Assistantship, if possible, try finding other sources of income. The managers for this position are sadistic people who (still?) think that managers have to treat employees like crap in order to be important or show authority. Be prepared for racist, sexist and down right disrespectful comments towards you in addition to tasks that include renovating and maintaining building such as cleaning windows and doors, moving furniture to different rooms and then back to the same place and even scrubbing bathroom floors. Note that the major problem is not doing these tasks but having to do them as punishment just for being in a "lower position" as graduate students (which by the way, are people with bachelors degrees).

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Greenville, SC
pros: ICAR is a state of the art facility.  There are a lot of brilliant people and cool projects to work on.
cons: The automotive department is run by engineers in all places, the downside of which is they are lacking is areas such as counseling and guidance.  The work ethic is incredible all around which leads to a high stress environment.

review_title: Great library in an OK school
pros: Laidback environment for faculty, a little less so for staff. Good pay and job security for the area. Tenure is relatively easy to achieve compared to faculty librarian jobs at other R1 schools. Employee experience at the library depends heavily on your supervisor - mine is great, but other units have nightmare potential.
cons: Achieving goals is often more a matter of who you know than anything else. No room for growth/promotions within the library and very few options for employment for spouses in the local area. The entire school is beholden to the football schedule.

pros: The only pro is the Tuition Benefits they allow for full time employees.
cons: Low paying for classified staff.  No promotion within. A who you know employment, promotion place.

pros: Was able to acquire a master's degree while earning some money on the side. Very independent work but professors and other students are always there to help when needed. Great atmosphere, especially at the football games.
cons: There are limited things to do outside of the University. Although the professors are extremely approachable and helpful, they are often busy and so getting quality one-on-one time can sometimes be difficult.

pros: The typical pros associated with working in higher education. Generally, flexibility of schedule, a good work-life balance, ability to take courses free of charge (employees only, not dependents) after one year, a stimulating and interesting work environment among a relatively diverse group of faculty, students and staff. The location is great from an outdoors perspective: fantastic hiking, biking, and water sports opportunities. Sports fans will love on-campus division 1 athletics and intramural sports. Excellent gym, climbing wall, pool, and workout facilities available to staff for a reasonable fee. Geographically, Clemson is a bit isolated, but a very beautiful place to work.
cons:
This is tricky, and I don't want this to sound like sour grapes. I think as with any large institution, an employee's experience is largely dependent on their particular area, and their immediate working relationships. So one department or unit may be a very healthy working environment, while another may be absolutely toxic. I've worked now here for over two years and find myself unfortunately in the latter. 

There seems to be no accountability to upper management for the completely unprofessional actions of a select number of managers and directors in a central, highly-visible office on campus. Decentralized liaisons who have to work with colleagues in this area are completely at a loss about the level of poor communication, unprofessional actions, backstabbing, blaming, and just overall terrible working environment. Petty disputes can spill over into evaluations and cause all sorts of headaches for employees. This is one problem of the centralized-decentralized model that is in use for a number of areas on campus. 

Overall, I've tried working within my own academic unit to address these issues, and while I feel genuinely supported within my academic unit's reporting structure, I have been largely unsuccessful in making an improvement to these external working relationships with colleagues in the central office. I do this as a committed team member trying to make a better a toxic situation for all parties, but systemically, there doesn't seem to be much incentive to improve things. 

Again, I stress that it is largely dependent on which area you are employed - but before you consider employment here, just know that there are some major organizational problems in place for at least some working areas. It's disappointing enough that I am planning on leaving after only 2.5 years here. At least four other colleagues I work with directly have either left or are in the process of leaving this particular office, and all within the past six months. All are career professionals in higher ed, and I'm afraid that Clemson is losing talent because of these organizational challenges. Another caveat that I'll mention is that I am a part-time graduate student here, and have had an incredibly good experience from my within my academic department. So it's not all bad.

pros: Passion persists throughout Clemson University; passion for the town, passion for the university, passion for athletics, passion for the people. Most people are genuinely happy to be at Clemson which makes working there all the more enjoyable.
cons: Given that Clemson University a state university and one without a professional school, the university goes as the economy goes. Salaries in certain departments may not be as competitive as they are at other schools. But cost of living and the benefits of Clemson can often outweigh what difference there is.

review_title: A big scam! I give one star just because I cannot give less.
pros: I cannot barely see any.
cons: Almost everything. The offered salary (at least in my case) is completely below the average. Health plans are way expensive, with high deductible, and without the fulfillment  of the requirements that apply to international employees, hence requiring further expenses to cover such requirements. The research quality is very poor and there is no clear rules about compensation and career development plans for postdocs. Assistance for international employees is very bad especially concerning VISA issues and alike.

review_title: No Growth, No Movement, Poor Management
job_title: Student Services Coordinator in Clemson, SC
pros:
*They do not fire people - the worse you do at your job, the greater the chance they will move you into an upper level position to pass you onto someone else. 
*You do get both personal leave and sick leave and it does accrue rather quickly.
cons:
* Hiring decisions are based on who you know, not based on experience, skills or fit - amazing people are passed over all the time
* Inability to reevaluate decisions once they have been made even if they are detrimental to students and staff
*There are no opportunities for upward movement- you are stuck in your position & the institution acts as if you should be thankful to have a job
* Low pay
* To get a raise, we were told to get a job offer from another company and there are no raises unless the state mandates it
* They do not value education and will not compensate employees for the education they have (ironic for a higher education institution)
* HR is incompetent and is there for the supervisor, not the employee
*  Too many office politics - it is like working with a bunch of middle school girls who hate each other
* Too many times where this person is married to this other person or is related or is best friends and that is how people get hired or put into higher positions - if you are not from Clemson or well connected to the people who currently work here, you will be looked over and ignored for everything 
* You may work in a building that is not ADA accessible, does not have proper heat/AC, and does not have consistent plumbing
* There are offices that are set-up in such a way that violate federal rules (ex: FERPA) and management turns a blind eye and does not care to look into solutions
* Lack of resources for staff members
* Hiring practices are inconsistent across colleges and within departments in the same college
* Voicing your opinion will get your ostracized - this is a no new ideas place
* Great people leave all the time so turnover is high

job_title: Natural Resources Agent in Florence, SC
pros: Great camaraderie and community to work with. State benefits are good, and they try and make sure everyone has a good work-life balance. You really do get paid to learn, and have the opportunity to further your education on the University's dime while employed.  Flexible schedule.
cons: Pay is not great, sometimes you have to work a lot of weekends during busy seasons. Not a lot of guidance when starting.

pros: At Child enrichment center I really enjoyed working as my colleagues were cooperative and the director was well organised and disciplined. Most of parents were Professor at  Clemson University so I had very educated environment.
cons: Most of my assistant teacher were students from Clemson University and after being trained they leave and I have to train other new teacher.

review_title: Amazing freedom, crazy deadlines, ego crazed professors.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Greenville, SC
pros: The freedom to create and explore the scientific world. The tools you are given are truly drool-worthy and you will miss every second of the resources given to you by Clemson University.
cons: The upper-level professors are fueled by ego and make you feel completely worthless many times. The pay in Greenville was also pretty low, as the cost of living is much higher than the programs on the main campus in Clemson.

pros: I was a graduate assistant working for the Pre-Collegiate Programs Office, which exists to run summer academic and sports camps for youth. The office also handles risk management issues that come along with having youths on a college campus. Pro: Doing this job gave me free tuition and you get to see the direct results of your work.
cons: My manager treated me (and other grad assistants) as if we were actual employees that only had work...rather than 20-25 hours of work, 9-12 hours of coursework, teaching requirements and theses or dissertations to write.

job_title: Customer Relations and Learning Tech in Clemson, SC
pros: People are really nice. As a student the work is not too hard. The hours are flexible with class schedules. I work in the Hardware department which isn't too bad.
cons: The ticketing system you work with is rather annoying. The hardware room is always really cold. In my position I have to filed a lot of repetitive questions which can get frustrating,

review_title: Good Education, Stepping Stone to Full Time Position
pros: Very good educational value, interesting projects to work on and people to work in my experience, typically a relaxed work environment
cons: This is academia, so progress is slow and deadlines are soft (report deadlines are hard, but prototype and testing deadlines are much more lax)

pros: Staff members were very knowledgeable on their subjects and extremely helpful. The lab supervisor was willing to answer all of my questions and made sure I left the university ready to work in any research facility. I worked in one of the labs in the Life Sciences building.
cons: The project I was assigned to had been going on for many years and was still going on when I left, it would have been nice to leave with some results. I do not have any complaints about the university itself.

pros: Do not have to worry about the issue of work life balance. Because research is not real work, and being a researcher typically means you will not have a life.
cons: long working hours, low pay, limited social life. need to balance the high course work load  and your researches especially during final weeks

pros: Professors are of top quality and caliber. There are a lots of good projects in the EE department. The administrative staff is very supportive.
cons: The main campus is not as big as some of the other universities. There is not much industry around Clemson, so placements are not that aggressive compared to some of the other places.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Greenville, SC
pros: Great research opportunities, the chance to work with expert professors, exposure to companies at CU-ICAR.
cons: Common Ph.D. student woes including low pay, especially for the Greenville area, high workload and little respect by the faculty.  The egotistical nature of the faculty makes it difficult to get things done when interdepartmental resources need to be shared.

pros: It is a very easy going place to work.  It really depends on your professor.  A university is really the kind of place where you get out what you put into it.
cons: I t can be a bit bureaucratic at times.  It also seems as though many time procedures get in the way of actual work

pros: Clemson truly has a family-like atmosphere that's impossible not to love. People are always willing to help if you need anything and higher-ranking people are happy to set up a time to talk to you so you can advance in your position/career.
cons: Many of the employees have busy schedules, so can be hard to get a hold of every once in a while.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Clemson, SC
pros: Of course it depends on the department, program, and their available budgets, but I found that the research and teaching assistantship salary/stipends were, on average, much higher at Clemson University that many other schools.
cons: Personally, I haven't experienced any cons working at Clemson University, but again this depends on the program and department and faculty/staff.

job_title: Venue Operations Manager (Hendrix Student Center) in Clemson, SC
pros: The environment is academic in general and understanding when it comes to academic schedule conflicts. The pay is decent for an on-campus job, considering I was a student. Working with fellow students was great and the management is laid back.
cons: The hours can get a bit hairy as college students have odd schedules. I would frequently be scheduled to work late and closing shifts, and then early opening shifts the next morning, which is difficult sometimes during tough school weeks.

pros: Clemson University is located in beautiful Clemson, SC and is a very safe campus, regardless of time of day. The state benefits are good.
cons: The parking problems seem to get worse each year. Seems like lots of money is spent on non-critical projects, where many older buildings could be renovated. There are very limited opportunities for growth within the university. The salaries are very low compared to industry standards.

pros: Everyone is friendly, and there's a lot of innovation going on.  World class creativity, research, & engineering without pretension.  The benefits are nice.  The area is gorgeous right at the foot of the Blue Ridge.
cons: Compensation.  Also, some people miss what a gem this place is and use it as a stepping stone rather than investing their time & efforts in its future.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Clemson, SC
pros:
Offers great health insurance plan if you don't have one.
Professors offer great advice on teaching and preparing for your classroom.
Great educational technology at your disposal if you choose to look for it and ask questions.
Very nice area and friendly atmosphere.
cons: Compensation could be a little higher for the amount of work in addition to classes taken for a graduate degree.

review_title: Fun and easiest job you'll ever have
pros:
Everyone's a student here and a fun place to work at. 
Flexible days and hours, you signup for the times that you can work. 
Can choose from multiple shifts from housing security, building lockup or drive tiger transit.
Good relations among coworkers.
cons:
Since its an organisation run by students, most times professionalism is not maintained.
Some people in upper ranks may tend to be harsh and abuse power but only some of them.

pros: Large University focused on research, lots of opportunity for you to expand your knowledge and skills.  Great people for the most part that work here, getting around town is relatively easy with the public transit
cons: Middle of nowhere, some adjacent cities like Greenville that offer some culture.  Clemson, however, is college town USA most of the time with a horde of undergraduates dominating the town and patronizing really terrible franchises for food.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Greenville, SC
pros: Excellent - you get to learn about the various responsibilities associated with teaching graduate and undergraduate students on a variety of courses - be it developing the syllabus and class schedule, working on making presentations, or actually teaching them, and then finally designing exams and assignments and grading them to check their progress. Of course, if the course has lab component, another bonus.
cons: No cons really - I would say take it!

review_title: Good experience but room for improvement.
pros: Tuition benefits through assistantship; Quality education; In a small college town; Setting on lake and near mountains; School spirit; People know that Clemson is a quality institution and that will help with future employment
cons: Good ol' boy network; Conservative views of many employees and students; Lack of diversity and support of diversity; Clemson seems to continually hire its own graduates and lacks diversity in educational background in some departments

pros:
-The people at Clemson are like a family
-Pay compensation is fair
-Great resources as a University for students and employees
-Cost of living cheap
cons:
-Location: the town of Clemson is very small (but alternatively, it is close to greenville)
-None other to speak of

pros: I had very flexible hours and never had to work after 5pm. Got school holidays and vacations off. Got to make connections with the school staff that were helpful when it came time for recommendations.
cons: I got paid only minimum wage and could only work until my total sum pay equalled my financial aid grant.

pros: Clemson as a whole has good holidays and hours. The town is great and the University spirit is high.
cons: The jobs are very dependent on department and supervisor. The organization is large and there is not enough over sight. The pay is not comparable to jobs in industry.  I experienced lots of pressure to work more hours and cover other peoples jobs with out receiving compensation. As with many academic institutions, tenure is everything.

review_title: A great experience as a work study student in the Chemistry Stockroom
job_title: Chemistry Stockroom Assistant in Clemson, SC
pros: Working in the chemistry stockroom as a work study student allowed me a lot of freedom to create my own schedule and take on the responsibility of helping to run labs for over 2,500 students per semester.
cons: You have to be wise about managing your hours so that you still have plenty of time so that you can get enough studying done as well.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Saratoga Springs, NY
pros:
Worked as a Teaching Assistant.
1) You get to work with really intelligent, warm people.
2) University resources.are fantastic for a knowledge hungry person.
cons: Pay could have been a bit better, but that's grad school for ya. Your tuition does get waived, so there's that.

pros: My coworkers and team are fantastic! The culture and atmosphere are energetic, inclusive and supportive. We truly are a family!
cons: There’s an opportunity to work with many different characters and personalities, some posing a challenge. However, I’ve learned a lot and grown from this challenge.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Clemson, SC
pros: Friendly atmostphere, if you're into athletics then its a great place to be. The weather is great most of the time and its in a beautiful part of South Carolina.
cons: A LOT wrong. They charge assistantship students actual tuition, thus making the assistantship basically worthless. Teaching too many classes to qualify. No incentive for faculty members to graduate students with any speed.

review_title: Great education and Great place to work/live
job_title: Post Doctoral Researcher in Clemson, SC
pros:
Free to work at your own pace
Lots of opportunities
Helpful faculty
Life around is not like a big city so don['t expect that but it is peaceful
cons:
Some typical upper management nonsense but usually does not get in the way of everyday life.
Sometimes hard to change policies no matter how many people don't approve of it.
Must have a car.

pros: Great university to be at and great setting to work in. Support is usually easy to find and the people are willing to help.
cons: A bit of distance from those running to program to those actually tutoring. They seem to not understand how students learn.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Fort Collins, CO
pros: For the most part the professors did not micromanage the time of the RA or TA. This was advantageous as it gave the student more freedom of concept over their work.
cons: No HR staff made it hard for working relationships. That is there were no clearly expressed guidelines on the type of relationship that was expected between the RA/TA's and the professors and other students

review_title: A great relaxed place to work and learn
job_title: Research Specialist III in Greenville, SC
pros: An opportunity to work with great people in a great area.  Learning opportunities are endless, and success depends on your effort and enthusiasm.
cons: As with most Higher Education institutions, compensation can be limited relative to other industry jobs.  Often priorities end up competing between educational and research missions which can be a challenge if your focus is more on one or the other.
